data.text:
# Plan 9 Stack on Windows 11 (No Go)

Removing Go-based options. All remaining solutions are C or Limbo.

## Path 1: WSL2 + plan9port (C)

Still the cleanest path. plan9port is pure C.

```powershell
# Enable WSL2 (admin PowerShell)
wsl --install -d Ubuntu-24.04
```

After reboot, in WSL:

```sh
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y build-essential libx11-dev libxext-dev libxt-dev \
    libfontconfig1-dev libfreetype6-dev

git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9
cd ~/plan9 && ./INSTALL

echo 'export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9 PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

plumber &
acme &
```

Acme appears as native Windows window via WSLg.

---

## Path 2: 9front VM + drawterm (C)

Pure Plan 9. drawterm is C, connects to 9front VM.

```powershell
# Enable Hyper-V
Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Hyper-V -All

# Download 9front ISO
$iso = "$env:USERPROFILE\Downloads\9front.iso.gz"
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "http://9front.org/iso/9front-10522.amd64.iso.gz" -OutFile $iso

# Download drawterm (C, native Windows binary)
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://9front.org/releases/drawterm/drawterm-windows-amd64.exe" -OutFile "$env:USERPROFILE\drawterm.exe"
```

Create VM, install 9front, then connect:
```powershell
& "$env:USERPROFILE\drawterm.exe" -h <vm-ip> -u glenda
```

---

## Path 3: Inferno (Limbo + C runtime)

Native Windows, no WSL. Inferno is the Plan 9 successor from Bell Labs.

```powershell
# Clone Inferno
git clone https://github.com/inferno-os/inferno-os $env:USERPROFILE\inferno
cd $env:USERPROFILE\inferno

# Requires Visual Studio Build Tools (C compiler)
# Download from: https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/visual-cpp-build-tools/
```

Build with `mk` (Inferno's make):
```cmd
set ROOT=%USERPROFILE%\inferno
mkconfig.bat
mk nuke
mk install
```

Run:
```cmd
%USERPROFILE%\inferno\Windows\386\bin\emu.exe
```

Inferno includes `acme` (the editor), `wm` (window manager), and the plumber.

---

## Path 4: Native plan9port via MSYS2 (Experimental)

Compile plan9port directly on Windows using MSYS2's X11.

```powershell
# Install MSYS2
winget install MSYS2.MSYS2

# In MSYS2 MINGW64 shell:
pacman -S mingw-w64-x86_64-gcc make git
pacman -S mingw-w64-x86_64-libx11 mingw-w64-x86_64-libxt mingw-w64-x86_64-fontconfig

git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9
cd ~/plan9
./INSTALL
```

Requires VcXsrv or similar X server running.

---

## Comparison (No Go)

| Approach | Language | Setup | Integration |
|----------|----------|-------|-------------|
| WSL2 + plan9port | C | Easy | WSLg native |
| 9front + drawterm | C | Medium | VM isolated |
| Inferno | Limbo/C | Medium | Native .exe |
| MSYS2 + plan9port | C | Hard | X server needed |

---

## Recommendation

**WSL2 + plan9port** - Least friction, pure C, WSLg handles display.

```sh
# After WSL installed, one command:
sudo apt install -y build-essential libx11-dev libxext-dev libxt-dev libfontconfig1-dev && \
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9 && cd ~/plan9 && ./INSTALL && \
echo 'export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9 PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin' >> ~/.bashrc && source ~/.bashrc && \
plumber & acme
```

# After WSL installed, one command:

echo 'export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9 PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin' >> ~/.bashrc && source ~/.bashrc && \
plumber & acme

data.text:
# Plan 9 Mouse-Focused Productivity Stack

The Plan 9 philosophy: **everything is text, the mouse is primary, programs are simple and compose through the plumber**.

## Core Mapping

| Category | Your Current | Plan 9 Alternative |
|----------|-------------|-------------------|
| Shell | zsh + oh-my-zsh + starship | **rc** (plan9port) |
| Multiplexer | tmux | **rio** (window manager IS the multiplexer) |
| Monitor | btop + proc + duf + dust | **stats** + acme scratch panes |
| Nav | yazi + zoxide + fzf + eza | **acme** (click directories) + **walk** |
| Search | ripgrep + fd + bat | **grep -n** in acme (middle-click results) |
| Git | lazygit + delta | **acme git commands** (click to execute) |
| Edit | neovim / emacs | **acme** or **sam** |
| Utils | jq + tldr + thefuck | **acme tags** (custom command buttons) |
| Vibe | fastfetch | **winwatch** or none (utilitarian) |

## The Stack

### 1. Foundation: plan9port
```sh
# Install plan9port (provides rio, acme, sam, 9term, rc, plumber)
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port $HOME/plan9
cd $HOME/plan9 && ./INSTALL
export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9
export PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin
```

### 2. Window Manager: rio
- **No tabs, no decorations** - just overlapping windows
- Right-click anywhere = window menu (new, resize, move, delete)
- Middle-click = paste selection
- Sweep to create new windows (draw a rectangle)

### 3. Editor/IDE/Everything: acme
The centerpiece. Acme is:
- Text editor
- File browser (click directory = list contents)
- Shell (middle-click any command = execute)
- IDE (plumber handles "go to definition")

**Mouse chording:**
| Action | Mouse |
|--------|-------|
| Select | Left-drag |
| Execute | Middle-click |
| Look/Open | Right-click |
| Cut | Left-drag, then Middle-click during drag |
| Paste | Left-click, then Middle-click |
| Snarf (copy) | Left-drag, then Right-click during drag |

### 4. Plumber: Click-to-Action
Configure `$HOME/lib/plumbing`:
```
# Click filename:line ΓåÆ open in acme at line
type is text
data matches '([.a-zA-Z0-9_/\-]+):([0-9]+)'
plumb to edit
plumb client $editor
arg isfile $1
data set $file
attr add addr=$2

# Click URL ΓåÆ open browser
type is text
data matches 'https?://[^ ]+'
plumb to web
plumb start firefox $0

# Click .go file ΓåÆ open in acme
type is text
data matches '[a-zA-Z0-9_\-./]+\.go'
arg isfile $0
plumb to edit
plumb client $editor
```

### 5. Shell: rc
```rc
# ~/.rcrc
fn cd { builtin cd $* && pwd }
fn l { ls -l $* }
fn g { grep -n $* }  # line numbers for plumbing
```

### 6. Git Workflow (in acme)
Create a scratch window, type these as your "tag bar":
```
git status | git diff | git add -p | git commit | git push | git log --oneline -20
```
Middle-click any command to execute. Output appears in the window.

### 7. Monitoring (in acme)
Create a `+watch` window with tag:
```
watch -n2 'df -h; echo ---; free -h; echo ---; uptime'
```
Or use Plan 9's native **stats** for graphical system monitoring.

### 8. Alternative Implementations

If pure plan9port feels too spartan:

| Tool | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **edwood** | Go rewrite of acme, slightly modernized |
| **acme2k** | Acme with TrueType fonts |
| **A** | Acme-inspired editor in Go |
| **vis** | Modal editor with sam's structural regex |
| **wio** | Wayland rio-inspired compositor |

## The Philosophy Shift

| TUI Stack | Plan 9 Stack |
|-----------|--------------|
| Keyboard shortcuts | Mouse chords |
| Separate tools | One tool (acme) |
| Config files | Per-window tags |
| Fuzzy finding | Click exactly what you see |
| Plugins | Plumber rules |
| Status bars | Just text in windows |

## Minimal Install

```sh
# plan9port (acme, rio, sam, rc, plumber, 9term)
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9 && cd ~/plan9 && ./INSTALL

# Add to ~/.zshrc or ~/.profile
export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9
export PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin

# Start
plumber  # background process
acme     # your new home
```

## Reality Check

The Plan 9 approach trades:
- **Lost:** Fuzzy finding, syntax highlighting, git TUI, pretty prompts
- **Gained:** Composability, mouse-driven flow, zero config, text-as-UI

Most practical path: **Use acme as your IDE, keep rio for window management, keep your existing shell for complex scripting.**

# Click .go file ΓåÆ open in acme

git status | git diff | git add -p | git commit | git push | git log --oneline -20

# Add to ~/.zshrc or ~/.profile
export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9
export PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin

# Start
plumber  # background process
acme     # your new home

Shell: zsh + oh-my-zsh + starship 
Multiplexer: tmux
Monitor: btop + proc + duf + dust
Nav: yazi + zoxide + fzf + eza mag 
Search: ripgrep + fd + bat 
Git: lazygit + delta 
Edit: neovim / emacs
Utils: jq + tldr + thefuck
Vibe: fastfetch

Propose a plan9 mouse focused alternative for productivity to the above

thinking.text:
The user wants to run a Plan 9-style mouse-focused productivity stack on Windows 11. This is challenging because:

1. plan9port is designed for Unix-like systems (Linux, macOS, *BSD)
2. rio requires X11
3. Windows doesn't have X11 natively

Options to consider:

1. **WSL2 + WSLg** - Run plan9port in WSL2, use WSLg for GUI (X11/Wayland forwarding)
2. **Native Windows ports** - Are there any?
3. **9front in VM** - Run actual 9front (modern Plan 9 fork) in a VM
4. **Cygwin/MSYS2** - Possibly compile plan9port?
5. **Inferno** - Limbo-based OS that runs on Windows natively

Let me think about what's actually practical:

**WSL2 + WSLg approach:**
- WSL2 can run Linux binaries
- WSLg provides native X11/Wayland support (built into Windows 11)
- plan9port should compile and run
- acme, sam, 9term would work
- rio might work but would conflict with Windows window management

**Native alternatives:**
- **Acme2k** - Has Windows support?
- **Edwood** - Go-based, might cross-compile
- **A (golang acme)** - Cross-platform
- **Acme SAC** - Stand-alone complex, has Windows builds

**9front VM:**
- Run 9front in QEMU/Hyper-V
- Full Plan 9 experience
- drawterm to connect from Windows

**Inferno:**
- Runs natively on Windows
- Has acme-like editor (acme-sac)
- Uses Limbo instead of C
- Actually from Bell Labs, same lineage

Let me research what's actually available:

1. **plan9port on WSL2** - Most direct path


2. **9front in Hyper-V** - Gives the authentic experience
3. **Inferno** - Native Windows support with the same design philosophy
4. **drawterm** - Allows connecting to a 9front or Plan 9 server from Windows
5. **Acme SAC** - Standalone acme implementation available for Windows

I should focus on approaches that balance setup simplicity, feature completeness, and how well they integrate with existing Windows workflows.

data.text:
# Plan 9 Stack on Windows 11

Three paths, in order of practicality:

## Path 1: WSL2 + WSLg (Recommended)

WSLg provides native X11 support in Windows 11. plan9port runs directly.

### Setup

```powershell
# Enable WSL2 (admin PowerShell)
wsl --install -d Ubuntu-24.04
wsl --set-version Ubuntu-24.04 2

# Reboot, then in WSL:
```

```sh
# In WSL Ubuntu
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y build-essential libx11-dev libxext-dev libxt-dev \
    libfontconfig1-dev libfreetype6-dev xfonts-base

# Clone and build plan9port
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port $HOME/plan9
cd $HOME/plan9
./INSTALL

# Add to ~/.bashrc
echo 'export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'export PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

# Start plumber (background)
plumber &

# Launch acme
acme &
```

Acme windows appear as native Windows windows via WSLg.

### Integration with Windows

```sh
# In WSL ~/.bashrc - access Windows files
alias winfiles='cd /mnt/c/Users/$USER'

# Plumb Windows paths - add to ~/lib/plumbing
# Rewrite Windows paths to WSL paths
type is text
data matches 'C:\\([^\s]+)'
data set /mnt/c/$1
plumb to edit
```

### Launcher Script

Create `%USERPROFILE%\plan9.bat`:
```batch
@echo off
wsl -d Ubuntu-24.04 -e bash -lc "plumber & acme"
```

---

## Path 2: 9front in Hyper-V (Pure Experience)

Run actual modern Plan 9 (9front fork) in a VM. Full rio, full experience.

### Setup

```powershell
# Enable Hyper-V (admin PowerShell)
Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Hyper-V -All

# Download 9front ISO
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "http://9front.org/iso/9front-10522.amd64.iso.gz" -OutFile "$env:USERPROFILE\Downloads\9front.iso.gz"

# Extract (requires 7-Zip or gzip)
# Then create VM in Hyper-V Manager:
# - Generation 2
# - 2GB RAM
# - 16GB disk
# - Boot from ISO
```

### Connect with drawterm

```powershell
# Download drawterm for Windows
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://9front.org/releases/drawterm/drawterm-windows-amd64.exe" -OutFile "$env:USERPROFILE\drawterm.exe"

# Connect to your 9front VM
& "$env:USERPROFILE\drawterm.exe" -h <vm-ip> -u glenda
```

drawterm gives you a Plan 9 window on Windows - full rio/acme inside.

---

## Path 3: Native Windows Alternatives

### A. Acme SAC (Standalone Complex)

Inferno-hosted acme that runs natively on Windows.

```powershell
# Download Inferno
git clone https://github.com/inferno-os/inferno-os $env:USERPROFILE\inferno
cd $env:USERPROFILE\inferno

# Build (requires Visual Studio Build Tools)
.\mkconfig.bat
.\mk.bat nuke
.\mk.bat install
```

### B. Edwood (Go-based Acme)

Cross-platform acme reimplementation.

```powershell
# Requires Go
go install github.com/rjkroege/edwood@latest

# Run
edwood
```

### C. A (Minimal Acme in Go)

```powershell
go install 9fans.net/A@latest
A
```

---

## Comparison

| Approach | Fidelity | Setup | Windows Integration |
|----------|----------|-------|---------------------|
| WSL2 + plan9port | 95% | Easy | Good (WSLg) |
| 9front VM + drawterm | 100% | Medium | Isolated |
| Edwood (Go) | 80% | Easy | Native |
| Inferno/Acme SAC | 85% | Hard | Native |

---

## Recommended: WSL2 Quick Start

```powershell
# One-liner setup (run in admin PowerShell, then reboot)
wsl --install -d Ubuntu-24.04
```

After reboot, in WSL:

```sh
# Full install
sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y build-essential libx11-dev libxext-dev libxt-dev libfontconfig1-dev
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9 && cd ~/plan9 && ./INSTALL
echo 'export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9 PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin' >> ~/.bashrc && source ~/.bashrc
plumber & acme &
```

---

## Mouse Setup

Windows 11 + WSLg handles 3-button mouse natively. If you have a 2-button mouse:

| Physical | Emulated |
|----------|----------|
| Left | Left (select) |
| Right | Right (look) |
| Left+Right together | Middle (execute) |

Or in acme, use keyboard modifiers:
- **Alt+Click** = Middle-click (execute)
- **Ctrl+Click** = Alternative middle-click

Configure in `$HOME/plan9/acme/acme.c` or use Edwood which has configurable bindings.

---

## File Access

| Location | WSL Path | Windows Path |
|----------|----------|--------------|
| Windows C: | `/mnt/c/` | `C:\` |
| WSL home | `~/` | `\\wsl$\Ubuntu-24.04\home\<user>` |
| Windows home | `/mnt/c/Users/<user>` | `%USERPROFILE%` |

Edit Windows files directly in acme:
```
B /mnt/c/Users/user/Documents/code/
```

# Download Inferno

cd $env:USERPROFILE\inferno

# Build (requires Visual Studio Build Tools)

.\mk.bat install

# Requires Go

# Run
edwood

go install 9fans.net/A@latest
A

# One-liner setup (run in admin PowerShell, then reboot)
wsl --install -d Ubuntu-24.04

# Full install
sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y build-essential libx11-dev libxext-dev libxt-dev libfontconfig1-dev
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9 && cd ~/plan9 && ./INSTALL
echo 'export PLAN9=$HOME/plan9 PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin' >> ~/.bashrc && source ~/.bashrc
plumber & acme &
B /mnt/c/Users/user/Documents/code/

data.richText: {"root":{"children":[{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"can we compile it with jart/cosmopolitan instead of running it in wsl2?","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"root","version":1}}
data.text: can we compile it with jart/cosmopolitan instead of running it in wsl2?

thinking.text:
The user doesn't want Go-based solutions. So I need to remove:
- Edwood (Go)
- A (Go)

That leaves:
1. WSL2 + plan9port (C) - still good
2. 9front in Hyper-V - still good
3. Inferno - uses Limbo, not Go

Let me also think about other native Windows options that don't use Go:
- plan9port compiled via MSYS2/Cygwin? Possible but painful
- Inferno - Limbo language, C runtime
- drawterm - C

I should revise the response to remove Go options and focus on the C-based solutions.

The user wants to compile plan9port using Cosmopolitan Libc (jart/cosmopolitan) to create Actually Portable Executables (APE) that run natively on Windows without WSL2.

This is an interesting idea. Let me think about the feasibility:

**Cosmopolitan Libc:**
- Creates "fat binaries" that run on Linux, macOS, Windows, FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD
- Single executable works everywhere
- Uses the APE format (Actually Portable Executable)
- Includes X11 support? That's the question...

**plan9port dependencies:**
- X11 (libX11, libXext, libXt) - This is the blocker
- Font rendering (fontconfig, freetype)
- Standard C library

**The problem:**
plan9port's GUI (acme, rio, sam) requires X11. Cosmopolitan doesn't include X11 bindings.

**Possible approaches:**

1. **plan9port's native graphics layer** - plan9port has a `devdraw` abstraction. Could we port devdraw to use Cosmopolitan's framebuffer/graphics primitives?

2. **Use plan9port's macOS Cocoa backend** - plan9port has a Cocoa backend for macOS that doesn't use X11. Could we adapt this for Windows GDI?

3. **Compile only non-GUI tools** - rc, mk, sam (command-line mode), grep, etc. could potentially be compiled with Cosmopolitan

4. **drawterm with Cosmopolitan** - drawterm has its own graphics abstraction, might be more portable

Let me look at what's realistic:

**Realistic: Non-GUI tools**
- rc (shell)
- mk (make)
- sam -d (sam in download/terminal mode)
- 9p (9P client)
- grep, sed, awk Plan 9 versions
- yacc, lex


- various utilities

**Hard but possible: GUI with custom backend**
- Would need to write a Windows GDI or DirectX backend for devdraw
- Or use SDL2 (which Cosmopolitan has some support for)
- Cosmopolitan has `__nt_` functions for Windows native calls, so a GDI backend might be feasible but would require significant porting work

The most practical path forward is compiling the command-line utilities first, since they don't depend on X11. GUI tools would need either a new graphics backend targeting Windows GDI or an SDL2 implementation, both of which represent substantial engineering effort.

The user is asking for a Plan 9-style, mouse-focused alternative to their current terminal-based productivity stack. Plan 9 from Bell Labs had a very different philosophy - it was heavily mouse-centric with the three-button mouse being central to the UI, and had a minimalist but powerful approach.

Let me think about Plan 9's philosophy and tools:
- **acme** - The text editor that's also a file manager, shell, and IDE. Everything is text, everything can be clicked.
- **rio** - The window manager (successor to 8┬╜)
- **sam** - The text editor with structural regular expressions
- **plumber** - Message passing between applications (click on a file path, it opens in editor; click on URL, it opens in browser)
- **9term** - The terminal that's mouse-aware
- **rc** - The shell

Plan 9 alternatives and spiritual successors that run on modern systems:

**Window Manager:**
- **rio** (plan9port) - Actual Plan 9 rio running on Unix
- **plan9port/9wm** - 9wm window manager
- **wio** - Wayland compositor inspired by rio

**Editor (the centerpiece):**
- **acme** (plan9port) - The full acme experience
- **acme2k** - Acme with modern fonts
- **edwood** - Go implementation of acme
- **vis** - Vim-like with sam's structural regex

**Terminal:**
- **9term** (plan9port) - Mouse-aware terminal
- **st** with modifications - Suckless terminal (not Plan 9 but suckless philosophy)

**File Navigation:**
- In acme, you just click directories
- **walk** - Plan 9's find replacement

**Plumbing:**
- **plumber** (plan9port) - The actual Plan 9 plumber

**Search:**
- **grep** in acme works by middle-clicking


- **sam** for structural text processing

The core stack would be rio as the window manager, acme as the unified editor and command interface, 9term for mouse-aware terminal interaction, and rc as the shell. The plumber ties it all together, letting you click on file paths and URLs to open them directly. Git workflows happen within acme windows where you click commands to execute them, and plan9port provides access to the full suite of Plan 9 utilities.

data.text:
>Plan 9 Mouse-Focused Productivity Stack
The Plan 9 philosophy: everything is text, the mouse is primary, programs are simple and compose through the plumber.
Core Mapping
Category	Your Current	Plan 9 Alternative
Shell	zsh + oh-my-zsh + starship	rc (plan9port)
Multiplexer	tmux	rio (window manager IS the multiplexer)
Monitor	btop + proc + duf + dust	stats + acme scratch panes
Nav	yazi + zoxide + fzf + eza	acme (click directories) + walk
Search	ripgrep + fd + bat	grep -n in acme (middle-click results)
Git	lazygit + delta	acme git commands (click to execute)
Edit	neovim / emacs	acme or sam
Utils	jq + tldr + thefuck	acme tags (custom command buttons)
Vibe	fastfetch	winwatch or none (utilitarian)
The Stack
1. Foundation: plan9port
# Install plan9port (provides rio, acme, sam, 9term, rc, plumber)git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port $HOME/plan9cd $HOME/plan9 && ./INSTALLexport PLAN9=$HOME/plan9export PATH=$PATH:$PLAN9/bin
2. Window Manager: rio
No tabs, no decorations - just overlapping windows
Right-click anywhere = window menu (new, resize, move, delete)
Middle-click = paste selection
Sweep to create new windows (draw a rectangle)
3. Editor/IDE/Everything: acme
The centerpiece. Acme is:
Text editor
File browser (click directory = list contents)
Shell (middle-click any command = execute)
IDE (plumber handles "go to definition")
Mouse chording:
Action	Mouse
Select	Left-drag
Execute	Middle-click
Look/Open	Right-click
Cut	Left-drag, then Middle-click during drag
Paste	Left-click, then Middle-click
Snarf (copy)	Left-drag, then Right-click during drag
4. Plumber: Click-to-Action
Configure $HOME/lib/plumbing:
# Click filename:line ΓåÆ open in acme at linetype is textdata matches '([.a-zA-Z0-9_/\-]+):([0-9]+)'plumb to editplumb client $editorarg isfile $1data set $fileattr add addr=$2# Click URL ΓåÆ open browsertype is textdata matches 'https?://[^ ]+'plumb to webplumb start firefox $0# Click .go file ΓåÆ open in acmetype is textdata matches '[a-zA-Z0-9_\-./]+\.go'arg isfile $0plumb to editplumb client $editor
5. Shell: rc
# ~/.rcrcfn cd { builtin cd $* && pwd }fn l { ls -l $* }fn g { grep -n $* }  # line numbers for plumbing
6. Git Workflow (in acme)
Create a scratch window, type these as your "tag bar":
git status | git diff | git add -p | git commit | git push | git log --oneline -20
Middle-click any command to execute. Output appears in the window.
7. Monitoring (in acme)
Create a +watch window with tag:
watch -n2 'df -h; echo ---; free -h; echo ---; uptime'
Or use Plan 9's native stats for graphical system monitoring.>

Now make it run on windows 11

# plan9port + Cosmopolitan Libc

Interesting idea. Let's assess feasibility.

## The Challenge

plan9port GUI tools (acme, rio, sam) depend on X11:
```
libX11, libXext, libXt, libfontconfig, libfreetype
```

Cosmopolitan doesn't include X11. So we need to either:
1. Compile only non-GUI tools (easy)
2. Write a new graphics backend for devdraw (hard)
3. Use Cosmopolitan's framebuffer/SDL path (medium)

---

## Path 1: Non-GUI Tools (Works Now)

These plan9port tools have no X11 dependency:

| Tool | Function |
|------|----------|
| `rc` | Plan 9 shell |
| `mk` | Plan 9 make |
| `sam -d` | sam in terminal mode |
| `9p` | 9P filesystem client |
| `grep` | Plan 9 grep |
| `sed` | Plan 9 sed |
| `awk` | Plan 9 awk |
| `yacc` | Parser generator |
| `hoc` | Calculator |
| `dc` | RPN calculator |

### Build with Cosmopolitan

```sh
# Get Cosmopolitan
mkdir -p ~/cosmo && cd ~/cosmo
wget https://cosmo.zip/pub/cosmos/bin/cosmos
chmod +x cosmos

# Clone plan9port
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9

# Build rc shell as APE
cd ~/plan9/src/cmd/rc
~/cosmo/cosmos cc -o rc.com *.c -I../../include -L../../lib -l9
```

**Problem:** plan9port's build system (`mk`) is tightly integrated. Would need to:
1. First build mk natively
2. Extract individual tool sources
3. Compile each with cosmocc

### Extraction Script

```sh
#!/bin/sh
# Extract standalone tools from plan9port for Cosmopolitan build

PLAN9=$HOME/plan9
COSMO=$HOME/cosmo
OUT=$HOME/p9cosmo

mkdir -p $OUT/src $OUT/include $OUT/lib

# Copy headers
cp -r $PLAN9/include/* $OUT/include/

# Tools without X11 deps
for tool in rc mk grep sed awk hoc dc; do
    cp -r $PLAN9/src/cmd/$tool $OUT/src/
done

# lib9 (core library) - need to strip X11 parts
cp $PLAN9/src/lib9/*.c $OUT/lib/
# Remove: graphics.c, notify.c (X11-dependent)
rm -f $OUT/lib/graphics.c $OUT/lib/notify.c
```

---

## Path 2: GUI via devdraw Abstraction (Medium Effort)

plan9port already has a `devdraw` abstraction layer:
```
src/cmd/devdraw/
Γö£ΓöÇΓöÇ x11-draw.c      # X11 backend (Linux)
Γö£ΓöÇΓöÇ osx-draw.c      # Cocoa backend (macOS)  
Γö£ΓöÇΓöÇ devdraw.c       # Core logic
ΓööΓöÇΓöÇ ...
```

**Strategy:** Write `win-draw.c` using Windows GDI or Cosmopolitan's primitives.

### Cosmopolitan has:
- `__nt_CreateWindowEx` - Windows native
- `__nt_GetDC`, `__nt_BitBlt` - GDI calls
- Basic framebuffer support

### Skeleton win-draw.c

```c
// src/cmd/devdraw/win-draw.c
#include <windows.h>
#include "devdraw.h"

static HWND hwnd;
static HDC hdc;
static BITMAPINFO bmi;

void
gfx_main(void)
{
    WNDCLASS wc = {0};
    wc.lpfnWndProc = WndProc;
    wc.lpszClassName = "plan9";
    RegisterClass(&wc);
    
    hwnd = CreateWindowEx(0, "plan9", "acme",
        WS_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW, CW_USEDEFAULT, CW_USEDEFAULT,
        800, 600, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL);
    
    ShowWindow(hwnd, SW_SHOW);
    
    // Message loop with plan9port integration
    MSG msg;
    while(GetMessage(&msg, NULL, 0, 0)) {
        TranslateMessage(&msg);
        DispatchMessage(&msg);
    }
}

void
gfx_flush(Rectangle r, u32int
 *data)
{
    // Blit plan9port's image buffer to Windows DC
    SetDIBitsToDevice(hdc, r.min.x, r.min.y,
        r.max.x - r.min.x, r.max.y - r.min.y,
        0, 0, 0, r.max.y - r.min.y,
        data, &bmi, DIB_RGB_COLORS);
}
```

This is ~500 lines of C to fully implement.

---

## Path 3: drawterm is Easier

drawterm already has multiple graphics backends and is designed for portability.

```sh
git clone https://github.com/9front/drawterm
cd drawterm

# It has:
# - gui-x11/   (X11)
# - gui-osx/   (Cocoa)  
# - gui-win32/ (Windows GDI) <-- Already exists!
# - gui-wl/    (Wayland)
```

**drawterm already compiles on Windows natively.** 

### Build drawterm with Cosmopolitan

```sh
cd drawterm
# Modify Make.config to use cosmocc
CC=cosmocc
make CONF=win32
```

This gives you a drawterm.com that connects to a 9front/Plan 9 server.

---

## Realistic Assessment

| Component | Cosmopolitan Feasibility | Effort |
|-----------|-------------------------|--------|
| rc, mk, grep, sed, awk | Yes | Low (days) |
| sam -d (terminal) | Yes | Low |
| lib9, libbio, libregexp | Yes | Low |
| devdraw (new Windows backend) | Yes | Medium (weeks) |
| acme, sam (GUI) | Yes, after devdraw | Low after devdraw |
| rio | Hard (window manager) | High |
| drawterm | Already has win32 | Low |

---

## Quickest Win: drawterm.com

```sh
# Clone drawterm
git clone https://github.com/9front/drawterm
cd drawterm

# Get cosmocc
mkdir -p ~/cosmo && cd ~/cosmo
wget https://cosmo.zip/pub/cosmocc/cosmocc.zip
unzip cosmocc.zip

# Patch Makefile for Cosmopolitan
cd ~/drawterm
cat > Make.cosmopolitan <<'EOF'
CC=~/cosmo/bin/cosmocc
AS=~/cosmo/bin/cosmoas
AR=~/cosmo/bin/cosmor
CFLAGS=-I. -Iinclude -Iposix-win32 -I~/cosmo/include
LDFLAGS=-L~/cosmo/lib
EOF

make CONF=win32 -f Make.cosmopolitan
# Output: drawterm.com (runs on Windows, Linux, macOS, *BSD)
```

This gives you the full Plan 9 experience (rio, acme, sam) via connecting to a 9front server - and the client binary runs everywhere.

---

## Want Full Native acme.com?

That requires the devdraw Windows backend. ~2-3 weeks of C work. If you want to pursue this, the steps are:

1. Fork plan9port
2. Create `src/cmd/devdraw/win-gdi.c` 
3. Implement: window creation, input events, buffer blitting
4. Compile with cosmocc
5. Result: `acme.com` runs on Windows/Linux/macOS

Interested in starting the devdraw port?

codeBlocks.content: libX11, libXext, libXt, libfontconfig, libfreetype

# Get Cosmopolitan
mkdir -p ~/cosmo && cd ~/cosmo
wget https://cosmo.zip/pub/cosmos/bin/cosmos
chmod +x cosmos

# Clone plan9port
git clone https://github.com/9fans/plan9port ~/plan9

# Build rc shell as APE
cd ~/plan9/src/cmd/rc
~/cosmo/cosmos cc -o rc.com *.c -I../../include -L../../lib -l9

#!/bin/sh
# Extract standalone tools from plan9port for Cosmopolitan build

PLAN9=$HOME/plan9
COSMO=$HOME/cosmo
OUT=$HOME/p9cosmo

mkdir -p $OUT/src $OUT/include $OUT/lib

# Copy headers
cp -r $PLAN9/include/* $OUT/include/

# Tools without X11 deps
for tool in rc mk grep sed awk hoc dc; do
    cp -r $PLAN9/src/cmd/$tool $OUT/src/
done

# lib9 (core library) - need to strip X11 parts
cp $PLAN9/src/lib9/*.c $OUT/lib/
# Remove: graphics.c, notify.c (X11-dependent)
rm -f $OUT/lib/graphics.c $OUT/lib/notify.c

src/cmd/devdraw/
Γö£ΓöÇΓöÇ x11-draw.c      # X11 backend (Linux)
Γö£ΓöÇΓöÇ osx-draw.c      # Cocoa backend (macOS)  
Γö£ΓöÇΓöÇ devdraw.c       # Core logic
ΓööΓöÇΓöÇ ...

git clone https://github.com/9front/drawterm
cd drawterm

# It has:
# - gui-x11/   (X11)
# - gui-osx/   (Cocoa)  
# - gui-win32/ (Windows GDI) <-- Already exists!
# - gui-wl/    (Wayland)

cd drawterm
# Modify Make.config to use cosmocc
CC=cosmocc
make CONF=win32

# Clone drawterm
git clone https://github.com/9front/drawterm
cd drawterm

# Get cosmocc
mkdir -p ~/cosmo && cd ~/cosmo
wget https://cosmo.zip/pub/cosmocc/cosmocc.zip
unzip cosmocc.zip

# Patch Makefile for Cosmopolitan
cd ~/drawterm
cat > Make.cosmopolitan <<'EOF'
CC=~/cosmo/bin/cosmocc
AS=~/cosmo/bin/cosmoas
AR=~/cosmo/bin/cosmor
CFLAGS=-I. -Iinclude -Iposix-win32 -I~/cosmo/include
LDFLAGS=-L~/cosmo/lib
EOF

make CONF=win32 -f Make.cosmopolitan
# Output: drawterm.com (runs on Windows, Linux, macOS, *BSD)
